testTitle: Life in the UK Test - World Wars & 20th Century
testDescription: Comprehensive test covering World War I, World War II, social changes, political developments, and major events of the early to mid-20th century in Britain.

questions.stem: World War I began in which year?
questions.explanation: World War I began in 1914 when Britain declared war on Germany following the invasion of Belgium.

questions.stem: Who was the British Prime Minister at the start of World War I?
questions.explanation: H.H. Asquith was Prime Minister when Britain entered World War I in 1914. Lloyd George took over in 1916.

questions.stem: The Battle of the Somme occurred in 1916.
questions.explanation: True. The Battle of the Somme (1916) was one of the bloodiest battles of WWI, with enormous casualties on the first day.

questions.stem: Which new weapons were used in World War I?
questions.explanation: WWI saw the introduction of poison gas, tanks, and military aircraft. Nuclear weapons were developed later in WWII.

questions.stem: When did World War I end?
questions.explanation: World War I ended with the Armistice on November 11, 1918, at 11 AM. This is now remembered as Remembrance Day.

questions.stem: Women gained the right to vote during World War I.
questions.explanation: True. The Representation of the People Act 1918 gave women over 30 the right to vote, largely in recognition of their war effort.

questions.stem: Who led the suffragette movement?
questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst founded and led the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU), the most famous suffragette organization.

questions.stem: The Irish War of Independence took place from 1919-1921.
questions.explanation: True. The Irish War of Independence (1919-1921) led to the partition of Ireland and the creation of the Irish Free State.

questions.stem: When was the Irish Free State created?
questions.explanation: The Irish Free State was created in 1921 following the Government of Ireland Act 1920 and the Anglo-Irish Treaty.

questions.stem: The General Strike occurred in which year?
questions.explanation: The General Strike occurred in 1926, lasting 9 days and involving millions of workers supporting coal miners.

questions.stem: The BBC began radio broadcasts in the 1920s.
questions.explanation: True. The BBC began regular radio broadcasts in 1922, revolutionizing communication and entertainment in Britain.

questions.stem: What caused the economic depression of the 1930s?
questions.explanation: The Great Depression was caused by the 1929 stock market crash, bank failures, and collapse of international trade. WWII came later.

questions.stem: Who was Prime Minister during most of the 1930s?
questions.explanation: Stanley Baldwin was Prime Minister for most of the 1930s (1935-1937), with Chamberlain taking over until 1940.

questions.stem: World War II began when Germany invaded Poland.
questions.explanation: True. Britain declared war on Germany on September 3, 1939, two days after Germany invaded Poland.

questions.stem: Who became Prime Minister in 1940?
questions.explanation: Winston Churchill became Prime Minister in May 1940, replacing Neville Chamberlain during the crisis of WWII.

questions.stem: The Battle of Britain was fought in the air.
questions.explanation: True. The Battle of Britain (1940) was an air campaign where the RAF defended Britain against German bombing attacks.

questions.stem: What was the Blitz?
questions.explanation: The Blitz was the German bombing campaign against British cities, particularly London, from 1940-1941.

questions.stem: D-Day occurred on June 6, 1944.
questions.explanation: True. D-Day, the Allied invasion of Nazi-occupied France, began on June 6, 1944, in Normandy.

questions.stem: Which countries were Britain's main allies in WWII?
questions.explanation: Britain's main allies were the US, USSR, and Free France. Nazi Germany was the enemy, not an ally.

questions.stem: The NHS was established in 1948.
questions.explanation: True. The National Health Service (NHS) was established in 1948 by Aneurin Bevan, providing free healthcare for all.

questions.stem: Who founded the NHS?
questions.explanation: Aneurin Bevan, the Health Minister in Attlee's Labour government, founded the NHS in 1948.

questions.stem: Rationing continued after World War II ended.
questions.explanation: True. Food and other goods rationing continued into the 1950s due to post-war shortages and economic difficulties.

questions.stem: The Festival of Britain was held in which year?
questions.explanation: The Festival of Britain was held in 1951 to celebrate British achievements and boost morale after the war.

questions.stem: India gained independence in 1947.
questions.explanation: True. India gained independence on August 15, 1947, and was partitioned into India and Pakistan.
